instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN_R: What is P5VS4RS3_EN_R? P5VS4RS3_EN_R is an enable signal that turns on the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. The _R means the signal is asserted when the voltage is high(3.3v). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> .118v
threads.message:
I fucking HATE these <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards. They seem to break for no god damn reason, or they're so fragile they just die if you look at them wrong.

I'm working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had no liquid, but won't turn on. Measuring around, I get all my s5 voltages, and <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is present at <RESISTOR>R8141</RESISTOR>, but my pin 4 (<SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN_R</SIGNAL>) of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is .196v. I can't recall what the enable voltage should be here, but I'm pretty sure it should be 3.4v. I changed <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> together, and there's no change.

I hate this model board, and have no clue where to go next. My other enables are present on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, but I believe this missing enable voltage is why I have no power.

Thanks in advance for any help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> .118v
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> present even for a second???? <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present?? Voltage on <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> both pins???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> .118v
threads.message:
Thanks, Aprendiz. You're always a good help:

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is at 0v, I don't see a pulse. When I measured it the first time, it gave me .198--the same reading as pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. Now I just re-measured it, and it's at 0v, and now so is pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

VRTC is present (3.3v). Voltage at <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> pin 1: 3.3v, pin 2: 3.16v; <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> pin 1: 3.3v, pin 2: 3.06v; <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR> pin 1: 3.3v, pin 2: 3.3v; <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR> pin 1: 3.3v, pin 2: 3.3v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> .118v
threads.message: These boards will power cycle when anything is wrong in the power circuit. I doubt this "just" failed, check for corrosion in the usual spots, SMC, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, Pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> .118v
threads.message: Thanks duke. Yes, I've inspected the board incredibly well. Nothing looks bad at all. Only thing I can find is that pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is now 0v. It was .118v the very first time I measured it, then it went up to .198v, now it's a solid and steady 0v. All I've done is replace <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>. I'll probably just ditch this one and move on, it's seeming like a nightmare.
